data.name: All absolute paths lead to Root
data.description:
There can be an infinite number of them. When you have at least two directories in your filesystem, let's say the root of the filesystem and a home directory inside it (`/` and `/home`), you can have an infinity of __absolute paths__ leading to the root:
```
/
/home/..
/home/../home/..
/home/../home/../home/..
... and so on ...
```
All of these absolute paths point to the root of the filesystem, which __canonical path__ is `/`.

In this kata, you'll have to find all absolute paths of a given length corresponding to the directory pointed by a given canonical path in a given filesystem, according to the rules and definitions specified in the next section.

---

## Rules and definitions

- __[a path](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_(computing))__ "is a string of character used to uniquely identify a location in a directory structure", composed by at least one __component__ and zero or more occurences of a __delimiting character__
  - in this kata:
    - a __component__ is a substring of a path that doesn't contain `/`
      - except for the first component of a path, which is always `/` and corresponds to the root of the filesystem
    - `/` is always the __delimiting character__
      - except when it is the first character of a path
    - a path never ends with `/` 
      - except when the path is the canonical path to the root `/`

- __the absolute path__ : an absolute path is a path pointing to a directory in the filesystem _from the root of the filesystem_
  - examples:
    - `/` is an absolute path to the root of the filesystem
    - `/home/apple/Documents` is an absolute path to the directory `Documents` of the user `apple`
    - `/home/banana/Videos/Movies/claude_jutra` is an absolute path to the directory `claude_jutra` in the `Movies` directory in the `Videos` directory of the home directory of the user `banana`

- __the parent directory__ : `..` (_2 dots component_) is a valid component of a path that points to the parent directory of the current directory
  - the root `/` has no parent directory
  - examples:
    - `/home/..`: the last _2 dots component_ points to the parent directory of `/home`, which is `/`, the root of the filesystem
    - `/home/banana/..`: the last _2 dots component_ points to the parent directory of `/home/banana`, which is `/home`

- __the canonical path__ : the canonical path to a directory is _the shortest of all absolute paths_ leading to it
  - a canonical path _doesn't contain a component pointing to the parent directory_
    - examples:
      - the absolute paths `/home/..` and `/home/../home/..` point to the root, which canonical path is `/`
      - the absolute paths `/boot/../home/cherry` and `/boot/home/cherry/../cherry` point to the directory of the user cherry, which canonical path is `/home/cherry`

- __the length of an absolute path__ : the length of an absolute path is its number of components
  - examples:
    - `/` has one component
    - `/home` has two components: `/` and `home`
    - `/home/../home` has four components: `/`, `home`, `..` and `home` again
    
## Example

In this filesystem:
```
 └── /
    ├── boot
    ├── dev
    ├── etc
    └── home
       ├── apple
       │  ├── Documents
       │  ├── Downloads
       │  ├── Images
       │  └── Videos
       ├── banana
       │  ├── Documents
       │  ├── Downloads
       │  ├── Images
       │  └── Videos
       └── cherry
          ├── Documents
          ├── Downloads
          ├── Images
          └── Videos
```
All absolute paths of __length 5__ leading to the root, which canonical path is `/`, are:
```
/boot/../boot/..
/boot/../dev/..
/boot/../etc/..
/boot/../home/..
/dev/../boot/..
/dev/../dev/..
/dev/../etc/..
/dev/../home/..
/etc/../boot/..
/etc/../dev/..
/etc/../etc/..
/etc/../home/..
/home/../boot/..
/home/../dev/..
/home/../etc/..
/home/../home/..
/home/apple/../..
/home/banana/../..
/home/cherry/../..
```


## Input

- __root__ : a tree data structure, the root of the filesystem
  - each node in that tree is a directory and has the following fields:
    - __name__ : a string of alphabetical characters or `/` if the node is the root
    - __content__ : either the equivalent of `null` or a non-empty sequence of nodes, the directories in the current directory
    - __parent__ : either the equivalent of `null` or the node which is the parent directory of the current directory
- __to__ : a string, the _canonical path_ to some directory in the filesystem
  - that directory will always exist
- __length__ : an integer, the length of the _absolute paths_ corresponding to the the given _canonical path_
  - there will always be at least one absolute path of the given length corresponding to the directory pointed by the given canonical path in the filesystem

````if:python
In Python, the root of the filesystem is the following `Node` dataclass:
```python
@dataclass
class Node:
    name    : str
    content : Optional[list['Node']] = None
    parent  : Optional['Node'] = None

    def __hash__(self) -> int:
        return hash(id(self))
```
````
````if:java
In Java, the root of the filesystem is the following `Node` class:
```java
public class Node{
    public String name;
    public Node parent;
    public List<Node> content;
}
```
````
```if:javascript
In JavaScript, the root of the filesystem and each node are plain objects with the following fields:
- `name` : a string
- `content` : either `null` or an array of nodes
- `parent` : either `null` or a node
```
## Output

- a sequence of strings, representing all absolute paths of the given length leading to the directory pointed by the given canonical path

## Errors and messages

- __Input__ : a tree representation of the filesystem, from its root
- __Actual__ : a lexicographically sorted list of your output
- __Expected__ : a lexicographically sorted list of the expected sequence of absolute paths


---

Happy coding and may the given Root be with you.
